units.title: Generate mosaic cortical brain organoids (mCBOs)
units.text: pooling PSC lines (5,000 cells per line) before organoid generation and longitudinally profiled the resulting mCBOs through scRNA-seq at 50, 100 and 300 d of differentiation, following the same protocol previously used and benchmarked in our laboratory
units.rationale: This describes a clear experimental procedure for creating multiplexed organoids by pooling stem cells prior to differentiation.

units.title: Perform downstream multiplexing before scRNA-seq
units.text: CBOs were generated individually from the PSC lines and profiled at the same time points, pooling equal amounts of cells per line after organoid dissociation for single-cell library preparation.
units.rationale: This outlines a distinct protocol step for pooling cells after organoid growth but before sequencing library prep.

units.title: Longitudinally profile organoids via scRNA-seq
units.text: longitudinally profiled the resulting mCBOs through scRNA-seq at 50, 100 and 300 d of differentiation
units.rationale: This specifies actionable time points for molecular profiling during organoid development.

units.title: Assess proliferation rates in mCBOs via flow cytometry
units.text: longitudinally assessed the proliferation rate of organoids derived from individual lines in two differentiation replicates through flow cytometry-based cell cycle analysis.
units.rationale: This is a direct protocol step for measuring cell proliferation over time using a standardized method.

units.title: Demultiplex single-cell transcriptomes using demuxlet, souporcell, and Vireo
units.text: The single-cell transcriptomics datasets generated from both mosaic and downstream multiplexed organoids at early, mid and late stages of differentiation (Fig. 1b) were demultiplexed using three different state-of-the-art algorithms available for genetic demultiplexing (demuxlet27, souporcell28, Vireo29).
units.rationale: This specifies the exact computational tools and data inputs used for genotype deconvolution in the protocol.

units.title: Apply SCanSNP for improved genetic demultiplexing
units.text: we set out to develop a new method, SCanSNP (Fig. 3a), to overcome the observed limitations by (1) dividing the classification challenge into two steps, one for identity assignment and one for doublet detection and (2) measuring the genetic purity of each droplet to identify low-quality droplets and separate them from authentic doublets.
units.rationale: This details the novel computational protocol steps for SCanSNP, including its two-stage design and purity-based filtering.

units.title: Implement consensus call framework for demultiplexing
units.text: to consolidate deconvolution accuracy, we set a consensus call framework considering the strengths and weaknesses of each algorithm, including non-genetic-based tools for doublets and low-quality cell detection43,44, merging their outcomes into one combined output (Fig. 3b).
units.rationale: This describes a protocol for combining multiple algorithms into a unified, consensus-based identity assignment pipeline.

units.title: Benchmark demultiplexing tools with in silico multiplexed datasets
units.text: we benchmarked them with ground truth priors using (1) five in silico multiplexed datasets with varying degree of balance among genotypes
units.rationale: This specifies a controlled experimental method for validating demultiplexing accuracy using simulated data.

units.title: Benchmark demultiplexing tools with barcode-tagged experiments
units.text: and (2) two ad hoc experiments in which the different genotypes were barcode tagged before pooling.
units.rationale: This describes an empirical validation protocol using synthetic barcodes to test demultiplexing performance.

units.title: Confirm SCanSNP performance against cell ranger multi
units.text: The superior performance (comparison against cell ranger multi; Methods) delivered by SCanSNP was confirmed in the barcode-tagged datasets
units.rationale: This states a direct comparison protocol used to validate SCanSNP against a reference tool.
